text: In The Paradox of Choice: Why More Is Less, Barry Schwartz examines how having too many options can affect decision-making. He describes an experiment in which participants were presented with two tables of products: one offering 24 types of jam and another offering only 6. While more people stopped at the table with 24 options, they were less likely to make a purchase compared to those who visited the table with 6 options. Schwartz argues that having too many choices can overwhelm consumers, making it harder for them to commit to a decision. This finding suggests that ______.
question: Which choice most logically completes the text?
A: consumers are more likely to make purchases when they perceive a product to be of high quality.
B: limiting the number of options available may increase consumer satisfaction and purchasing behavior.
C: offering a wide variety of products is the most effective way to attract consumer attention.
D: consumers tend to be equally satisfied regardless of the number of options they are presented with.
explanation:
Choice B is the best answer. The experiment shows that fewer options led to more purchases, supporting the idea that limiting choices can improve decision-making and satisfaction.Choice A is incorrect. The text focuses on the effect of choice overload, not product quality, on consumer behavior.Choice C is incorrect. While a wide variety attracted more attention, it did not result in more purchases, contradicting this claim.Choice D is incorrect. The experiment demonstrates a clear difference in consumer behavior based on the number of options, invalidating this statement.
